SEARCH
Package sprouts

Interface Val<T extends @Nullable Object>

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the item held by this Val.
All Superinterfaces:
Maybe<T>
All Known Subinterfaces:
Var<T>, Viewable<T>
public interface Val<T extends @Nullable Object> extends Maybe<T>
A read only wrapper around an item which can be mapped to a weakly referenced Viewable to then be observed for changes using Actions registered through the Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) method, where the Channel is used to distinguish between changes from different sources (usually application layers like the view model or the view).
Use view() to access a simple no-op live view of the item of this property and register change listeners on it to react to state changes. When the Viewable is no longer referenced strongly in your code, then it will be garbage collected alongside all of its listeners.

The Channel supplied to the Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) method to register an Action callback is expected to be a simple constant, usually one of the From constants like for example From.VIEW_MODEL or From.VIEW. You may fire a change event for a particular channel using the fireChange(Channel) method or in case the property is also a mutable Var, then through the Var.set(Channel, Object).
Note that Var.set(Object) method defaults to the From.VIEW_MODEL channel.

If you no longer need to observe changes a Viewable created from this property, then you can remove any registered Action callback using the Observable.unsubscribe(Subscriber) method (Action is also a Subscriber).

Note that the name of this class is short for "value". Its API is inspired by the Optional API in the sense that it is a null safe wrapper around a single item, which may also be missing (null). The name of this class was deliberately chosen because it is short, concise and yet clearly conveys the same meaning as other names used to model this kind of pattern, like "property", "observable object", "observable value", "observable property", etc. Using Var and Val as names also allows for the distinction between mutable and immutable properties without having to resort to prefixes like "mutable" or "immutable" as part of types that are supposed to be used everywhere in your code.

Please take a look at the living sprouts documentation where you can browse a large collection of examples demonstrating how to use the API of this class.

See Also:
  • A mutable subclass of this class.
  • A weakly referenced, read only live view of mutable properties to be used for registering change listeners.

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    boolean
    allowsNull()
    A property will only allow null items if it was constructed with a "ofNullable(..)" factory method.
    static boolean
    equals(@Nullable Object o1, @Nullable Object o2)
    Val and Var implementations are expected to represent simple wrappers for data centric quasi value types! So two primitive arrays of integers for example would not be recognized as equal when calling one of their Object.equals(Object) methods because the method does not compare the contents of the two arrays, it compares the identities of the arrays! This method defines what it means for 2 property items to be equal.
    Val<T>
    fireChange(Channel channel)
    Triggers all observer lambdas for the given Channel.
    default @NonNull T
    get()
    This method is intended to be used for when you want to wrap non-nullable types.
    static int
    hashCode(Object o)
    Val and Var implementations require their own Object.hashCode() method because they are supposed to be viewed as data centric quasi value types! So two arrays of integer for example would not have the same hash code when calling Object.hashCode() on them.

  • Method Details

    • ofNullable

      static <T> Val<@Nullable T> ofNullable(Class<T> type, @Nullable T item)
      Use this factory method to create a new Val instance whose item may or may not be null.

      Example: 

      
      Val.ofNullable(String.class, null);
      Note that it is required to supply a Class to ensure that the property can return a valid type when Maybe.type() is called.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the wrapped item.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item wrapped by the property. This is used to check if the item is of the correct type.
      item - The initial item of the property. This may be null.
      Returns:
      A new Val instance.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the type is null.

    • ofNull

      static <T> Val<@Nullable T> ofNull(Class<T> type)
      A more concise version of ofNullable(Class, Object) which is equivalent to Var.ofNullable(type, null).
      The Val instances returned by this factory method, are nullable, which means their allowsNull() method will always yield true.
      Note that it is required to supply a Class to ensure that the property can return a valid type when Maybe.type() is called.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the wrapped item.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item wrapped by the property.
      Returns:
      A new Val instance.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the supplied type is null.

    • of

      static <T> Val<T> of(T item)
      This factory method returns a Val describing the given non-null item similar to Optional.of(Object), but specifically designed for use with Swing-Tree.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item held by the Val!
      Parameters:
      item - The initial item of the property which must not be null.
      Returns:
      A new Val instance wrapping the given item.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the supplied item is null. Use ofNullable(Class, Object) if the item may be null.

    • of

      static <T> Val<T> of(Val<T> toBeCopied)
      A factory method for creating a new Val instance which is effectively an immutable copy of the given Val. The provided Val must not contain a null item.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item held by the Val!
      Parameters:
      toBeCopied - The Val to be copied.
      Returns:
      A new Val instance.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the supplied Val is null.
      NoSuchElementException - If the item of the supplied Val is null.

    • ofNullable

      static <T extends @Nullable Object> Val<@Nullable T> ofNullable(Val<T> toBeCopied)
      A factory method for creating a new Val instance which is effectively an immutable copy of the given Val. The provided Val may contain a null item.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item held by the Val!
      Parameters:
      toBeCopied - The Val to be copied.
      Returns:
      A new Val instance.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the supplied Val is null. Does not throw however, if the item of the supplied Val is null.

    • get

      default @NonNull T get()
      This method is intended to be used for when you want to wrap non-nullable types. So if an item is present (not null), it returns the item, otherwise however NoSuchElementException will be thrown. If you simply want to get the item of this Val irrespective of it being null or not, use Maybe.orElseNull() to avoid an exception. However, if this result wraps a potentially nullable type, which is not intended to be null, please use Maybe.orElseThrow() or Maybe.orElseThrowUnchecked() to make this intention clear to the reader of your code!
      The Maybe.orElseThrowUnchecked() method is functionally identical to this method, but should be preferred in most cases.
      Returns:
      The non-null item described by this Val.
      Throws:
      NoSuchElementException - if no item is present.
      See Also:
      • Maybe.orElseThrowUnchecked()

    • or

      default Val<T> or(Supplier<? extends Maybe<? extends T>> supplier)
      If an item is present, returns a Val describing the item, otherwise returns a Val produced by the supplying function.
      Specified by:
      or in interface Maybe<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Parameters:
      supplier - the supplying function that produces a Val to be returned
      Returns:
      returns a Val describing the item of this Val, if an item is present, otherwise a Val produced by the supplying function.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the supplying function is null or produces a null result

    • map

      default Val<T> map(Function<T,T> mapper)
      If the item is present, applies the provided mapping function to it, and returns it wrapped in a new Val instance.
      If the item is not present, then an empty Val instance is returned.

      But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
      It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

      If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the view(Function) method instead. This is essentially the same as Optional.map(Function) but based on Val as the wrapper instead of Optional.

      Specified by:
      map in interface Maybe<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Parameters:
      mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
      Returns:
      A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

    • mapTo

      default <U> Val<U> mapTo(Class<U> type, Function<T,U> mapper)
      If the item is present, applies the provided mapping function to it, and returns it wrapped in a new Val instance.
      If the item is not present, then an empty Val instance is returned.

      But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
      It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

      If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the viewAs(Class, Function) method instead.

      Specified by:
      mapTo in interface Maybe<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
      Returns:
      A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

    • view

      default Viewable<T> view()
      Returns a no-op Viewable of this Val to be used for registering change listeners (see Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action)).
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!
      Returns:
      A weakly referenced Viewable to be used for registering change listeners.

    • viewIsPresent

      default Viewable<Boolean> viewIsPresent()
      Creates and returns a boolean property which is a live view of the Maybe.isPresent() flag of this property.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!
      Returns:
      A live view of the presence of an item in this property in the form of a Boolean property. So whenever the Maybe.isPresent() flag of this property changes, the item of the returned property will be updated to reflect the change.

    • viewIsEmpty

      default Viewable<Boolean> viewIsEmpty()
      Creates and returns a boolean property which is a live view of the Maybe.isEmpty() flag of this property.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!
      Returns:
      A live view of the absence of an item in this property in the form of a Boolean property. So whenever the Maybe.isEmpty() flag of this property changes, the item of the returned property will be updated to reflect the change.

    • viewAs

      default <U> Viewable<U> viewAs(Class<U> type, Function<T,U> mapper)
      Use this to create a live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function. So whenever the value of this property changes, the value of the new property will be updated based on the mapping function.

      Note: The mapping function is not allowed to map to null, but may need to handle null. Null must be mapped to an appropriate null object.

      The result is a non-nullable view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • view

      default <U> Viewable<U> view(U nullObject, Function<T,@Nullable U> mapper)
      Use this to create a live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function. So whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be updated based on the mapping function and null object.

      Note: The mapping function can map to null and may need to handle null. If the mapping function returns null or throws an exception, the view will contain the proved null object.

      The result is a non-nullable view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the resulting property.
      Parameters:
      nullObject - The null object to use if no item is present.
      mapper - The mapping function to apply to an item.
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function and null object.

    • view

      default <U> Viewable<U> view(U nullObject, U errorObject, Function<T,@Nullable U> mapper)
      Use this to create a live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function. So whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be updated based on the mapping function and null object.

      Note: The mapping function can map to null and may need to handle null. If the mapping function returns null, the view will contain the proved null object. If the mapping function throws an exception, the view will contain the proved error object.

      The result is a non-nullable view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the resulting property.
      Parameters:
      nullObject - The null object to use if no item is present.
      errorObject - The error object to use if an error occurs.
      mapper - The mapping function to apply to an item.
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function and null object.

    • viewAsNullable

      default <U> Viewable<@Nullable U> viewAsNullable(Class<U> type, Function<T,@Nullable U> mapper)

    • view

      default Viewable<T> view(Function<T,T> mapper)
      Use this to create a live view of this property based on a mapping function which maps the item of this property to an item of the same type as this property. So whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will be updated based on the mapping function. If you want to create a live view of a different type, use the viewAs(Class, Function) method instead.

      Note that this method will try to map value based item types like String, Integer, Double, etc. to the default value (or "null object") of their respective types, if the provided mapping function returns a null reference.
      So if the type of this property is a String, and the mapping function returns a null reference, then the resulting view property will always contain an empty string and its allowsNull() method will always return false.

      Also note that a property view may only contain null if the property it is based on was created with the "ofNullable(...)" factory method (in which case its allowsNull() method will return true). Otherwise, it will throw an exception when trying to map a null reference.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Parameters:
      mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • viewAsString

      default Viewable<String> viewAsString(String nullObject, Function<T,@Nullable String> mapper)
      Use this to create a String based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function and null object. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping function.

      Note: The mapping function can map to null and may need to handle null. If the mapping function returns null or throws an exception, the view will contain the proved null object.

      The result is a non-nullable String view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Parameters:
      nullObject - The null object to use if the mapping function returns null.
      mapper - The mapping function to map the item of this property to a String.
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • viewAsString

      default Viewable<String> viewAsString(Function<T,@Nullable String> mapper)
      Use this to create a String based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping function.

      Note: The mapping function can map to null and may need to handle null. If the mapping function returns null or throws an exception, the view will contain the "null object" of the String type, which is an empty string.

      The result is a non-nullable String view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Parameters:
      mapper - The mapping function to map the item of this property to a String.
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • viewAsString

      default Viewable<String> viewAsString()
      Use this to create a String based live view of this property through a new property based on the Object.toString() method used as the mapping function. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the Object.toString() mapping function.

      Note: null references within the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the String type, which is an empty string.

      The result is a non-nullable String view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • viewAsDouble

      default Viewable<Double> viewAsDouble(double nullObject, Function<T,@Nullable Double> mapper)
      Use this to create a Double based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function and null object. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping function.

      Note: The mapping function can map to null and may need to handle null. If the mapping function returns null, the view will contain the provided null object. If the mapping function throws an exception, the view will contain Double.NaN.

      The result is a non-nullable Double view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Parameters:
      nullObject - The null object to use if the mapping function returns null.
      mapper - The mapping function to map the item of this property to a Double.
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • viewAsDouble

      default Viewable<Double> viewAsDouble(Function<T,@Nullable Double> mapper)
      Use this to create a Double based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping function.

      Note: The mapping function can map to null and may need to handle null. If the mapping function returns null, the view will contain the "null object" of the Double type, which is 0.0. If the mapping function throws an exception, the view will contain Double.NaN.

      The result is a non-nullable Double view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Parameters:
      mapper - The mapping function to map the item of this property to a Double.
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • viewAsDouble

      default Viewable<Double> viewAsDouble()
      Use this to create a Double based live view of this property through a new property based on the Object.toString() and Double.parseDouble(String) methods used as the mapping functions. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping functions.

      Note: null references within the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the Double type, which is 0.0. If the item cannot be parsed, the item of the view will be Double.NaN.

      The result is a non-nullable String view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Returns:
      A Double property that is a live view of this property.

    • viewAsInt

      default Viewable<Integer> viewAsInt(int nullObject, Function<T,@Nullable Integer> mapper)
      Use this to create a Integer based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function and null object. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping function.

      Note: The mapping function can map to null and may need to handle null. If the mapping function returns null or throws an exception, the view will contain the provided null object.

      The result is a non-nullable Integer view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Parameters:
      nullObject - The null object to use if the mapping function returns null.
      mapper - The mapping function to map the item of this property to a Integer.
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • viewAsInt

      default Viewable<Integer> viewAsInt(Function<T,@Nullable Integer> mapper)
      Use this to create a Integer based live view of this property through a new property based on the provided mapping function. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping function.

      Note: The mapping function can map to null and may need to handle null. If the mapping function returns null, the view will contain the "null object" of the Integer type, which is 0. If the mapping function throws an exception, the view will contain 0.

      The result is a non-nullable Integer view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Parameters:
      mapper - The mapping function to map the item of this property to a Integer.
      Returns:
      A property that is a live view of this property based on the provided mapping function.

    • viewAsInt

      default Viewable<Integer> viewAsInt()
      Use this to create a Integer based live view of this property through a new property based on the Object.toString() and Integer.parseInt(String) methods used as the mapping functions. This means that whenever the item of this property changes, the item of the new property will also be updated based on the result of the mapping functions.

      Note: null references within the viewed property will always be mapped to the "null object" of the Integer type, which is 0. If the item cannot be parsed, the item of the view will be 0.

      The result is a non-nullable Integer view of the property. The reason for this design decision is that a view of a property is intended to be used as part of an application, where null can lead to exceptions and ultimately a confusing user experience.
      Warning:
      If you do not keep a strong reference to the Viewable returned by this method, then it will eventually be garbage collected alongside all of its change listeners.
      So if there are changes in this property afterward, the change listeners will not be called!

      Returns:
      A Integer property that is a live view of this property.

    • viewAsTuple

      default <U> Viewable<Tuple<U>> viewAsTuple(Class<U> type, Function<T,@Nullable Tuple<U>> mapper)
      Creates a live view of this property as a Tuple containing items of the specified type using the given mapping function which dynamically maps the current property item T to a Tuple<U>.

      The resulting view is automatically updated whenever the value of this property changes, meaning that the mapper Function<T, @Nullable Tuple<U>> is called with the new property item and the state of the view is updated with the result of said mapping function.

      The type parameter is used to obtain a default tuple instance (via Tuple.of(type)) which serves both as the fallback null object and error object. This means that if the mapping function returns null or throws an exception, the view will retain a default Tuple instance instead of propagating storing null, which is not allowed for this view.

      Warning: If you register change listeners on the returned view and do not maintain a strong reference to it, the view along with its listeners will eventually be garbage collected, and subsequent changes to this property will not trigger the listeners.

      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the element within the tuple.
      Parameters:
      type - The class representing the type of the tuple's element. This is used to create a default tuple instance.
      mapper - A function that maps the value of this property to a Tuple of type U. The function should handle null values appropriately.
      Returns:
      A live view of this property as a Tuple of type U.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either type or mapper is null.

    • viewAsAssociation

      default <K, V> Viewable<Association<K,V>> viewAsAssociation(Class<K> keyType, Class<V> valueType, Function<T,@Nullable Association<K,V>> mapper)
      Creates a live view of this property as a Association containing key-value pairs of the specified key type K and value type V using the supplied mapping function which dynamically maps the current property item T to a Association<K, V>.

      The resulting view is automatically updated whenever the value of this property changes, meaning that the mapper Function<T, @Nullable Association<K, V>> is called with the new property item and the state of the view is updated with the result of said mapping function.

      The keyType and valueType parameters are used to obtain a default association instance (via Association.between(keyType, valueType)) which serves both as the fallback null object and error object. This means that if the mapping function returns null or throws an exception, the view will retain an empty default Association instance instead of propagating storing null, which is not allowed for this view.

      Warning: If you register change listeners on the returned view and do not maintain a strong reference to it, the view along with its listeners will eventually be garbage collected, and subsequent changes to this property will not trigger the listeners.

      Type Parameters:
      K - The type of the key within the association.
      V - The type of the value within the association.
      Parameters:
      keyType - The class representing the type of the association's key. This is used to create a default association instance. This parameter must not be null.
      valueType - The class representing the type of the association's value. This is used to create a default association instance. This parameter must not be null.
      mapper - A function that maps the value of this property to an Association of type K, V. The function should handle null values appropriately.
      Returns:
      A live view of this property as an Association of type K, V.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either keyType, valueType, or mapper is null.

    • viewAsValueSet

      default <E> Viewable<ValueSet<E>> viewAsValueSet(Class<E> type, Function<T,@Nullable ValueSet<E>> mapper)
      Creates a live view of this property as a ValueSet containing items of the specified type E using the given mapping function which dynamically maps the current property item T to a ValueSet<E>.

      The resulting Viewable<ValueSet<E>> is automatically updated whenever the value of this property changes, meaning that the mapper Function<T, @Nullable ValueSet<E>> is called with the new property item and the state of the view is updated with the result of said mapping function.

      The type parameter is used to obtain a default value set instance (via ValueSet.of(type)) which serves both as the fallback null object and error object. This means that if the mapping function returns null or throws an exception, the view will retain a default ValueSet instance instead of propagating storing null, which is not allowed for this view.

      Warning: If you register change listeners on the returned view and do not maintain a strong reference to it, the view along with its listeners will eventually be garbage collected, and subsequent changes to this property will not trigger the listeners.

      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of the element within the value set.
      Parameters:
      type - The class representing the type of the value set's elements. This is used to create a default value set instance.
      mapper - A function that maps the value of this property to a ValueSet with type parameter E. The function is expected handle null values appropriately.
      Returns:
      A live view of this property as a ValueSet of type E.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either type or mapper is null.

    • id

      String id()
      Returns the name/id of the property which is useful for debugging as well as persisting their state by using them as keys for whatever storage data structure one chooses.
      For example, when converting a property based model to a JSON object, the id of the properties can be used as keys in the JSON object.
      Returns:
      The id which is assigned to this property.

    • withId

      Val<T> withId(String id)
      Use this method to create a new property with an id. This id is used to identify the property in the UI or as a key in a map, which is useful when converting your view model to a JSON object, or similar formats.

      You can retrieve the id of a property by calling the id() method.
      An id may not be null, please use the Sprouts.defaultId() constant or an empty string to indicate that a property has no id.

      Parameters:
      id - The id of the property, which is used to identify it. It may not be null, please use the Sprouts.defaultId() constant
      Returns:
      A new Val instance with the given id.

    • hasNoID

      default boolean hasNoID()
      A convenient method to check if this property has not been assigned an id.
      This is the same as calling !hasID() or id().equals(Sprouts.defaultId()).
      Returns:
      True when this property has not been assigned an id or the id is equal to the Sprouts.defaultId() constant.

    • hasID

      default boolean hasID()
      A convenient method to check if this property has been assigned an id.
      This is the same as calling !id().equals(NO_ID).
      Returns:
      The truth value determining if this property has been assigned an id, or if id is not equal to the Sprouts.defaultId() constant.

    • fireChange

      Val<T> fireChange(Channel channel)
      Triggers all observer lambdas for the given Channel. Change listeners may be registered using the Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) method. Note that when the Var::set(T) method is called then this will automatically translate to fireChange(From.VIEW_MODEL). So it is supposed to be used by the view to update the UI components. This is in essence how binding works in Swing-Tree.
      Parameters:
      channel - The channel from which the item is set.
      Returns:
      The Val instance itself.

    • allowsNull

      boolean allowsNull()
      A property will only allow null items if it was constructed with a "ofNullable(..)" factory method. Otherwise, it will throw an IllegalArgumentException when trying to set a null reference. This flag cannot be changed after the property has been constructed!
      The purpose of this method is to warn the UI that this property can contain null items, so that it may throw an exception or do something else to handle this case. For many types of properties null is simply nonsensical, like String for example, where the absence of a value is represented by an empty string.
      Returns:
      true, if this property can contain null, false otherwise.

    • isMutable

      boolean isMutable()
      This method is used to determine if the property is mutable or not. A mutable property can be changed by calling the Var.set(T) method. An immutable property cannot be changed and will throw an exception when trying to do so.
      The purpose of this method is to warn the UI that this property can be changed, so that it may throw an exception or do something else to handle this case.
      Note that this is the inverse of isImmutable().
      Returns:
      true, if this property can be changed, false otherwise.

    • isImmutable

      default boolean isImmutable()
      This method is used to determine if the property is immutable or not. An immutable property cannot be changed by calling the Var.set(T) method and will throw an exception when trying to do so.
      The purpose of this method is to give the UI confidence in the fact that this property cannot be changed, so that it may make some assumptions based on that.
      Note that this is the inverse of isMutable().
      Returns:
      true, if this property can not be changed, false otherwise.

    • isLens

      default boolean isLens()
      This method is used to determine if the property is a lens or not. A lens is a property which observes a specific part of the item of a parent property, and is used to create a view of that part, which may also be modified using the Var.set(T) method.
      See Var.zoomTo(Function, BiFunction) and Var.zoomTo(Object, Function, BiFunction) for more information on how to create a lens.
      Returns:
      true, if this property is a lens, false otherwise.

    • isView

      default boolean isView()
      This method is used to determine if the property is a view or not. A view is a simple property which observes the item of another property, using a mapping function to create a new item based on the item of the parent property. This kind of property may only change its state when the parent property changes.
      See viewAs(Class, Function) and view(Object, Function) for more information on how to create a view.
      Returns:
      true, if this property is a view, false otherwise.

    • equals

      static boolean equals(@Nullable Object o1, @Nullable Object o2)
      Val and Var implementations are expected to represent simple wrappers for data centric quasi value types! So two primitive arrays of integers for example would not be recognized as equal when calling one of their Object.equals(Object) methods because the method does not compare the contents of the two arrays, it compares the identities of the arrays! This method defines what it means for 2 property items to be equal. So in this example it ensures that two Var instances wrapping different arrays but with the same contents are treated as the same items.
      Parameters:
      o1 - The first object which ought to be compared to the second one.
      o2 - The second object which ought to be compared to the first one.
      Returns:
      The truth value determining if the objects are equal in terms of their state!

    • hashCode

      static int hashCode(Object o)
      Val and Var implementations require their own Object.hashCode() method because they are supposed to be viewed as data centric quasi value types! So two arrays of integer for example would not have the same hash code when calling Object.hashCode() on them. This is because the method does not compare the contents of the two arrays!
      Parameters:
      o - The object for which a hash code is required.
      Returns:
      The hash code of the object.
